**Theorem.** Let $p$ be an odd prime. Then $-3$ is a quadratic residue
modulo $p$ if and only if $p \equiv 1\pmod{3}$.

*Proof.* Preliminary to the proof, we remark first that $-1$ is a
quadratic residue modulo $p$, where $p$ is an odd prime, if and only if
$p \equiv 1\pmod{4}$.

If $p \equiv 1\pmod{4}$ then
$$\left(\frac{-3}{p}\right) = \left(\frac{-1}{p}\right)\left(\frac{3}{p}\right) = \left(\frac{p}{3}\right).$$
Now if $p \equiv 3\pmod{4}$, then
$$\left(\frac{-3}{p}\right) = \left(\frac{-1}{p}\right)\left(\frac{3}{p}\right) = (-1)(-1)\left(\frac{p}{3}\right) = \left(\frac{p}{3}\right).$$
Thus,
$\displaystyle \left(\frac{-3}{p}\right) = \left(\frac{p}{3}\right)$,
and $\displaystyle \left(\frac{p}{3}\right)=1$ if and only if
$p \equiv 1\pmod{3}$. $\Box$
